column15: As of 2017, only launch was suborbital[1]
Var.: G, G+, GS, ECA, ES.
Launch Mercury. Atlas or Centaur upper stage.
Fully reusable. Expected as early as 2020, with suborbital spaceship tests beginning in the first half of 2019.
Launched Pioneer & Explorer probes. Var. A, B, C, D, E, G, J, L, M, N, 300, 900, 1X00, 4X00, 2X00, 3X00, 5X00
Launched Mars probes MGS to Phoenix Var.: 6000, 7000, and Heavy.
1 partial failure with Polyus spacecraft, 1 successful flight with Buran shuttle.

Upgrade to version 1.1 in 2013; upgrade to version FT in 2015 Launcher of Dragon capsule. One flight put primary but not secondary payload into correct orbit,[50] one rocket and payload were destroyed before launch in preparation for static fire[51] and thus is not counted. Falcon 9 Block 5 first launched 11th May 2018 with Bangabandhu 1, the first fully sized Bangladesh satellite.
Also 2 suborbital launches (HTV-2a). Var.: IV, IV Lite, IV HAPS, V. Derived from Peacekeeper missile
Designed for Soviet Manned Lunar Mission
Derived from the American Delta rocket
First stage uses the Russian RD-151 engine
Var.: K, M, Medium in development.
Var.: CA, XL, HP, 3S Launched moon probe Chandrayaan I, Mars probe Mangalyaan I
23 launches of Rokot; 2 launches of Strela
Saturn 1 family also included 6 suborbital test launches
Var.: X1, X2, A, D, G
Var.: Sputnik, Luna, Vostok-L, Vostok-K, Voskhod, Molniya, Molniya-L, Molniya-M, Polyot, Soyuz, Soyuz-L, Soyuz-M, Soyuz-U, Soyuz-FG, Soyuz-2, Soyuz-2-1v

Orbital ATK Boeing United Launch Alliance Aerojet Rocketdyne

column15: Two successful suborbital flights, one failed and one successful attempt to reach orbit. A test how small orbital rockets can be. The rocket has a mass of only 2.6 tonnes.
As of December 2018, design of the rocket has been completed and first developmental flight is to take place before May 2019.
Var.: I, II, IIIA, IIIB, IIIC, IIID, IIIE, 34D, IVA, IVB Gemini launcher
Var.: Paektusan based on Taepodong-1 missile; Unha based on Taepodong-2 missile.
